description.raw:
Add the concept of a sequence_index to runmanager.

The sequence index is an incrementing integer starting from zero each day for
each experiment script. It is stored on disk in
<experiment_shot_storage>/<script_name>/.next_sequence_index and accessed using
zlock so that it may be incremented atomically.

The sequence index may be used in the output folder format, which defaults to:
`output_folder_format = %%Y/%%m/%%d/{sequence_index:05d}`, resulting in output
folders like:
<shared_drive>/Experiments/<experiment_name>/<script_name>/2019/03/14/00006

The format string will be fed first to `strftime()`, then a call to `.format()`
with `sequence_index` and `sequence_timestamp` kwargs, where `sequence_timestamp` is
the time in format `'%Y%m%dT%H%M%S'`, which is the existing format used in
`sequence_id`s.

Allow the shot filename to also have its format configured, such as:
`filename_prefix_format = %%Y-%%m-%%d_{sequence_index:05d}_{script_basename}`,
resulting in shot filenames like:
`2019-03-14_00006_myscript_1.h5`

This is similarly passed through `strftime` and then `.format` with `sequence_index`,
`sequence_timestamp`, and `script_basename` kwargs.

`script_basename` is not allowed in the `output_folder_format` format string though, since we've for the moment hard-coded that the script basename is at the top level of the subfolder hierarchy under `experiment_shot_storage`, and it is more difficult to change that without breaking existing setups - I also don't really want to change it, despite some downsides, at the moment I think the script name at the top level is almost always what you want.

The pre-set `output_folder_format` in newly installed labconfigs will be:
`%%Y/%%m/%%d/{sequence_index:05d}`
which will also be the default if the setting is not present in the labconfig file. Since this setting already exists, this change won't break existing setups, which have it set already.

The pre-set `filename_prefix_format` in newly installed labconfigs will be:
`%%Y-%%m-%%d_{sequence_index:05d}_{script_basename}`
but if not present in labconfig files, `{sequence_timestamp}_{script_basename}`
will be used, to preserve the present behaviour of using the sequence id. This is necessary to not modify existing setups since the setting did not exist already.

For compatibility with lyse (which uses it to index the dataframe), the `sequence_id` is still saved to the h5 file, but other attributes are saved too. These are:

'script_basename': the basename of the script, i.e. myscript


'sequence_date': a string of the date only, i.e. 2019-03-14


'sequence_index': the sequence_index as an integer,


'sequence_id': the sequence_id, i.e. 20190314183955_myscript

The idea is that `script_basename`, `sequence_date` and `sequence_index` become an
alternative to `sequence_id` as a way of uniquely identifying a sequence. lyse
already has a labconfig setting where it uses the `sequence_index` if present to
index the dataframe (added for the  sake of Spielman fork shots which already
have `sequence_index`), but it has the issue that sequences cannot be fully uniquely
determined by that alone since the date and script name are needed too. So
the date and script name are added to the attrs for this purpose, but `sequence_id`
is retained for now, perhaps indefinitely since it also provides a timestamp for when the sequence was compiled. It is still useful even if it is not used in filenames or by lyse.

Refactored runmanager functions to achieve this. There is now a fairly monolithic function
new_sequence_details(), which returns the attrs, folder and filepath prefix for
the given labconfig settings and current time. It's all in one function because
the different pieces all use timestamps, and so to avoid races it either has to be
a single function call or the caller would need to carry around a datetime object.
Since it is not too complicated I made it a single function call, though the callers
are often ignoring one or more of its return values.

Removed generate_sequence_id, since the functions that accept a sequence_id
now accept the sequence_attrs dict instead (one entry of which is the sequence_id).
This and the modifying of other function call signatures is a backward incompatible
change in the sense of the API that runmanager exposes, but is backward-compatible
with how other labscript programs use the runmanager API, i.e. BLACS. So I think
this is acceptable - code using the runmanager API directly may need to change.
We could do a major version bump to indicate this.
description.html:
Add the concept of a sequence_index to runmanager.

The sequence index is an incrementing integer starting from zero each day for each experiment script. It is stored on disk in <experiment_shot_storage>/<script_name>/.next_sequence_index and accessed using zlock so that it may be incremented atomically.

The sequence index may be used in the output folder format, which defaults to: output_folder_format = %%Y/%%m/%%d/{sequence_index:05d}, resulting in output folders like: <shared_drive>/Experiments/<experiment_name>/<script_name>/2019/03/14/00006

The format string will be fed first to strftime(), then a call to .format() with sequence_index and sequence_timestamp kwargs, where sequence_timestamp is the time in format '%Y%m%dT%H%M%S', which is the existing format used in sequence_ids.

Allow the shot filename to also have its format configured, such as: filename_prefix_format = %%Y-%%m-%%d_{sequence_index:05d}_{script_basename}, resulting in shot filenames like: 2019-03-14_00006_myscript_1.h5

This is similarly passed through strftime and then .format with sequence_index, sequence_timestamp, and script_basename kwargs.

script_basename is not allowed in the output_folder_format format string though, since we've for the moment hard-coded that the script basename is at the top level of the subfolder hierarchy under experiment_shot_storage, and it is more difficult to change that without breaking existing setups - I also don't really want to change it, despite some downsides, at the moment I think the script name at the top level is almost always what you want.

The pre-set output_folder_format in newly installed labconfigs will be: %%Y/%%m/%%d/{sequence_index:05d} which will also be the default if the setting is not present in the labconfig file. Since this setting already exists, this change won't break existing setups, which have it set already.

The pre-set filename_prefix_format in newly installed labconfigs will be: %%Y-%%m-%%d_{sequence_index:05d}_{script_basename} but if not present in labconfig files, {sequence_timestamp}_{script_basename} will be used, to preserve the present behaviour of using the sequence id. This is necessary to not modify existing setups since the setting did not exist already.

For compatibility with lyse (which uses it to index the dataframe), the sequence_id is still saved to the h5 file, but other attributes are saved too. These are:

'script_basename': the basename of the script, i.e. myscript

'sequence_date': a string of the date only, i.e. 2019-03-14

'sequence_index': the sequence_index as an integer,

'sequence_id': the sequence_id, i.e. 20190314183955_myscript

The idea is that script_basename, sequence_date and sequence_index become an alternative to sequence_id as a way of uniquely identifying a sequence. lyse already has a labconfig setting where it uses the sequence_index if present to index the dataframe (added for the sake of Spielman fork shots which already have sequence_index), but it has the issue that sequences cannot be fully uniquely determined by that alone since the date and script name are needed too. So the date and script name are added to the attrs for this purpose, but sequence_id is retained for now, perhaps indefinitely since it also provides a timestamp for when the sequence was compiled. It is still useful even if it is not used in filenames or by lyse.

Refactored runmanager functions to achieve this. There is now a fairly monolithic function new_sequence_details(), which returns the attrs, folder and filepath prefix for the given labconfig settings and current time. It's all in one function because the different pieces all use timestamps, and so to avoid races it either has to be a single function call or the caller would need to carry around a datetime object. Since it is not too complicated I made it a single function call, though the callers are often ignoring one or more of its return values.

Removed generate_sequence_id, since the functions that accept a sequence_id now accept the sequence_attrs dict instead (one entry of which is the sequence_id). This and the modifying of other function call signatures is a backward incompatible change in the sense of the API that runmanager exposes, but is backward-compatible with how other labscript programs use the runmanager API, i.e. BLACS. So I think this is acceptable - code using the runmanager API directly may need to change. We could do a major version bump to indicate this.

title.raw: Add the concept of a sequence_index to runmanager.
title.html: Add the concept of a sequence_index to runmanager.

description:
Add the concept of a sequence_index to runmanager.

The sequence index is an incrementing integer starting from zero each day for
each experiment script. It is stored on disk in
<experiment_shot_storage>/<script_name>/.next_sequence_index and accessed using
zlock so that it may be incremented atomically.

The sequence index may be used in the output folder format, which defaults to:

folders like:
<shared_drive>/Experiments/<experiment_name>/<script_name>/2019/03/14/00006

The format string will be fed first to `strftime()`, then a call to `.format()`
with `sequence_index` and `sequence_timestamp` kwargs, where `sequence_timestamp` is
the time in format `'%Y%m%dT%H%M%S'`, which is the existing format used in
`sequence_id`s.

Allow the shot filename to also have its format configured, such as:
`filename_prefix_format = %%Y-%%m-%%d_{sequence_index:05d}_{script_basename}`,
resulting in shot filenames like:
`2019-03-14_00006_myscript_1.h5`

This is similarly passed through `strftime` and then `.format` with `sequence_index`,
`sequence_timestamp`, and `script_basename` kwargs.

`script_basename` is not allowed in the `output_folder_format` format string though, since we've for the moment hard-coded that the script basename is at the top level of the subfolder hierarchy under `experiment_shot_storage`, and it is more difficult to change that without breaking existing setups - I also don't really want to change it, despite some downsides, at the moment I think the script name at the top level is almost always what you want.

`%%Y/%%m/%%d/{sequence_index:05d}`
which will also be the default if the setting is not present in the labconfig file. Since this setting already exists, this change won't break existing setups, which have it set already.

The pre-set `filename_prefix_format` in newly installed labconfigs will be:
`%%Y-%%m-%%d_{sequence_index:05d}_{script_basename}`
but if not present in labconfig files, `{sequence_timestamp}_{script_basename}`
will be used, to preserve the present behaviour of using the sequence id. This is necessary to not modify existing setups since the setting did not exist already.

For compatibility with lyse (which uses it to index the dataframe), the `sequence_id` is still saved to the h5 file, but other attributes are saved too. These are:

'script_basename': the basename of the script, i.e. myscript


'sequence_date': a string of the date only, i.e. 2019-03-14


'sequence_index': the sequence_index as an integer,


'sequence_id': the sequence_id, i.e. 20190314183955_myscript

alternative to `sequence_id` as a way of uniquely identifying a sequence. lyse
already has a labconfig setting where it uses the `sequence_index` if present to
index the dataframe (added for the  sake of Spielman fork shots which already
have `sequence_index`), but it has the issue that sequences cannot be fully uniquely
determined by that alone since the date and script name are needed too. So
the date and script name are added to the attrs for this purpose, but `sequence_id`
is retained for now, perhaps indefinitely since it also provides a timestamp for when the sequence was compiled. It is still useful even if it is not used in filenames or by lyse.

Refactored runmanager functions to achieve this. There is now a fairly monolithic function
new_sequence_details(), which returns the attrs, folder and filepath prefix for
the given labconfig settings and current time. It's all in one function because
the different pieces all use timestamps, and so to avoid races it either has to be
a single function call or the caller would need to carry around a datetime object.
Since it is not too complicated I made it a single function call, though the callers
are often ignoring one or more of its return values.

Removed generate_sequence_id, since the functions that accept a sequence_id
now accept the sequence_attrs dict instead (one entry of which is the sequence_id).
This and the modifying of other function call signatures is a backward incompatible
change in the sense of the API that runmanager exposes, but is backward-compatible
with how other labscript programs use the runmanager API, i.e. BLACS. So I think
this is acceptable - code using the runmanager API directly may need to change.
We could do a major version bump to indicate this.

summary.html:
Add the concept of a sequence_index to runmanager.

The sequence index is an incrementing integer starting from zero each day for each experiment script. It is stored on disk in <experiment_shot_storage>/<script_name>/.next_sequence_index and accessed using zlock so that it may be incremented atomically.

The sequence index may be used in the output folder format, which defaults to: output_folder_format = %%Y/%%m/%%d/{sequence_index:05d}, resulting in output folders like: <shared_drive>/Experiments/<experiment_name>/<script_name>/2019/03/14/00006

The format string will be fed first to strftime(), then a call to .format() with sequence_index and sequence_timestamp kwargs, where sequence_timestamp is the time in format '%Y%m%dT%H%M%S', which is the existing format used in sequence_ids.

Allow the shot filename to also have its format configured, such as: filename_prefix_format = %%Y-%%m-%%d_{sequence_index:05d}_{script_basename}, resulting in shot filenames like: 2019-03-14_00006_myscript_1.h5

This is similarly passed through strftime and then .format with sequence_index, sequence_timestamp, and script_basename kwargs.

script_basename is not allowed in the output_folder_format format string though, since we've for the moment hard-coded that the script basename is at the top level of the subfolder hierarchy under experiment_shot_storage, and it is more difficult to change that without breaking existing setups - I also don't really want to change it, despite some downsides, at the moment I think the script name at the top level is almost always what you want.

The pre-set output_folder_format in newly installed labconfigs will be: %%Y/%%m/%%d/{sequence_index:05d} which will also be the default if the setting is not present in the labconfig file. Since this setting already exists, this change won't break existing setups, which have it set already.

The pre-set filename_prefix_format in newly installed labconfigs will be: %%Y-%%m-%%d_{sequence_index:05d}_{script_basename} but if not present in labconfig files, {sequence_timestamp}_{script_basename} will be used, to preserve the present behaviour of using the sequence id. This is necessary to not modify existing setups since the setting did not exist already.

For compatibility with lyse (which uses it to index the dataframe), the sequence_id is still saved to the h5 file, but other attributes are saved too. These are:

'script_basename': the basename of the script, i.e. myscript

'sequence_date': a string of the date only, i.e. 2019-03-14

'sequence_index': the sequence_index as an integer,

'sequence_id': the sequence_id, i.e. 20190314183955_myscript

The idea is that script_basename, sequence_date and sequence_index become an alternative to sequence_id as a way of uniquely identifying a sequence. lyse already has a labconfig setting where it uses the sequence_index if present to index the dataframe (added for the sake of Spielman fork shots which already have sequence_index), but it has the issue that sequences cannot be fully uniquely determined by that alone since the date and script name are needed too. So the date and script name are added to the attrs for this purpose, but sequence_id is retained for now, perhaps indefinitely since it also provides a timestamp for when the sequence was compiled. It is still useful even if it is not used in filenames or by lyse.

Refactored runmanager functions to achieve this. There is now a fairly monolithic function new_sequence_details(), which returns the attrs, folder and filepath prefix for the given labconfig settings and current time. It's all in one function because the different pieces all use timestamps, and so to avoid races it either has to be a single function call or the caller would need to carry around a datetime object. Since it is not too complicated I made it a single function call, though the callers are often ignoring one or more of its return values.

Removed generate_sequence_id, since the functions that accept a sequence_id now accept the sequence_attrs dict instead (one entry of which is the sequence_id). This and the modifying of other function call signatures is a backward incompatible change in the sense of the API that runmanager exposes, but is backward-compatible with how other labscript programs use the runmanager API, i.e. BLACS. So I think this is acceptable - code using the runmanager API directly may need to change. We could do a major version bump to indicate this.
